TopicTitle: Boeing P-8 Poseidon [Mostly a replica. I had no choice but to install four engines.]

Articles.Content:
And to the guy impersonating juanxlink, down vote our craft pages however much you want, but remember that the ratings have become meaningless. Congratulations, mr. troll.

Anyways, here's my Boeing P-8 Poseidon. It's still a work in progress, with aerodynamic refinement on the agenda, but I think this thing flies well for having over 18,000 units of liquid fuel and only four jet engines. Heck, without the four missiles, it cruises at 180 m/s.

While you're taking off, you have to wait until you reach 50-60 m/s and retract the rearmost impact gear. This will allow you to safely take off.

After you read the instructions above, you can actually fly this huge jet: https://www.dropbox.com/s/xtxd1fdq6wk3n2r/Poseidon%20Prototype%201_1.craft?dl=0

I also fixed the slight issue of landing gear explosions in flight. Also, don't fly this thing like a fighter. It flies like the real thing, which is based off of a passenger airliner with an extremely large fuel load.

Its armament consists of four supersonic cruise missiles, a MAD (magnetic anomaly detector) tail boom, and a small bomb bay for the yet to be installed countermeasure cartridge.

Now that I like, functional, practical and a good representation of the real thing! I made a BAe Nimrod R1 last night with the new flight model and it can now fly straight!

Good job sir!

Sam

Sam

Thank you.

Edited April 28, 2015 by Red Iron Crown
Nice craft,you can easily clip 2 engines into the others engines and make it a proper replica

Nice craft,you can easily clip 2 engines into the others engines and make it a proper replica

I was going to do so, but there's a poster lurking here that downvotes and insults any craft with clipped engines and parts.

This was my attempt at a balancing act, but it turned a 737 into a 707.

As long as it has enough thrust, I'm happy.

Thank you.
